data.text: Contents
Aim of Management of Reduced Fetal Movements (RFM) ........................................... 4
Subsequent Management in Patients who present with RFM ...................................... 5
Management of Patients who present with RFM before  weeks gestation ................ 7

Management of Patients who present with RFM after 24 weeks gestation but before 28 weeks gestation .............................................................................................................. 8
Management of Patients who present with RFM after  weeks gestation ................... 8
Introduction

Most women are familiar with the usual fetal movement pattern of their baby in utero. Women‘s perception of reduced fetal movements should be taken seriously and documented in the woman's health care records.
Women should be encouraged to seek midwifery medical advice if there is a significant reduction or change to their baby's usual pattern of movements.
Aims of management of reduced fetal movements
The specific aims are to:
Ascertain gestation and obstetric history
Ascertain fetal well-being, reassure the woman and exclude fetal death
Exclude fetal growth restriction or small for gestational age (SGA) baby
Delivery as appropriate
Assure more intensive assessment if appropriate
Definitions
Roles and responsibilities

The Specialist Nurse for Guidelines and Audit is responsible for ensuring clinical policies, guidelines and SOPs, are evidence-based and developed in line with national guidelines and following appropriate consultation.
The clinical director is responsible for the implementation of this guideline within the directorate.
The Head of Midwifery, maternity matrons and maternity managers are responsible for ensuring maternity staff are aware of the guideline and implement it.
The Obstetric Clinical Lead Consultant and Labour Ward Lead Consultant are responsible for ensuring the implementation of this guideline within the  clinical setting.
All maternity staff are responsible for ensuring they are familiar with this guideline in relation to their practice and have the appropriate skills to implement this guideline.
Antenatal management
The importance of monitoring fetal movements must be discussed at each
antenatal appointment from  weeks gestation. At the woman's 16  week antenatal appointment, the midwife must discuss the topic of their baby's
movements during pregnancy using the Tommy's patient information page from the  handheld records. This discussion must be documented in the woman's handheld
records directly on the Tommy's Leaflet page there is a section for the midwife to
date and sign as documentation of discussion with the woman. When discussing
fetal movements if the mother is not clear in her understanding then refer her back  to the leaflet, if she has any concerns she must be invited to attend the DAU.
If a woman feels a change in the pattern of fetal movements or cessation of fetal movements she must be advised to contact and attend the Day Assessment Unit (DAU) at Broomfield Hospital.

There is insufficient evidence to recommend formal fetal movement counting using specific parameters. Women must be advised to be aware of their baby's individual pattern of movements. Women who are concerned about RFM must not wait until the next day for assessment of fetal wellbeing.

Where the woman has contacted the midwife over the phone, the midwife must complete the appropriate telephone message proforma (which must be filed in the woman's lilac medical folder) and ask the woman to report to the maternity unit for further assessment and auscultation of the fetal heart.

The midwife taking a call from a woman reporting reduced fetal movements after  weeks gestation must complete both the appropriate telephone message proforma and the ‘Checklist for the required management of reduced fetal movements' proforma. The midwife based on DAU must file the completed form in the appropriate black folder and the midwife based at the MLU's should scan the emails to the audit midwife accordingly.

When a woman presents in a community or hospital setting with RFM, an attempt must be made to auscultate the fetal heart using a handheld Doppler to exclude fetal death. This must be done as soon as possible within half an hour of attendance to the unit.
If a woman presents in the community setting with no facility to auscultate the fetal heart, she must be referred immediately to the maternity unit for auscultation.
Women must be reassured that 70% of pregnancies with a single episode of reduced fetal movements are uncomplicated.

Women must be advised to be aware of their baby's individual pattern of movements. If they are concerned about a reduction in or cessation of fetal movements after 28+0 weeks of gestation, they must contact their maternity unit.

This information and advice must be documented in the woman's healthcare records in terms of a care pathway for these patients following their initial visit (Refer to the guideline entitled ‘Guideline for maternity record keeping including documentation in handheld records', register number 06036)

If a low risk woman is attending the Midwife-led Unit for reduced fetal movements on the first occasion and the CTG is found to be abnormal, the woman must attend the DAU, Broomfield where Oxford Sonicare CTG (Computerised CTG) monitoring must be undertaken.

A relevant history must be undertaken to assess risk factors for intrauterine growth  restriction (IUGR) or stillbirth. Midwives and obstetriciansmust be aware of the potential association of decreased fetal movements with key risk factors such as multiple consultations for RFM, IUGR, small-for-gestational-age (SGA) fetus, hypertension, diabetes, extremes of maternal age, primiparity, smoking, placental insufficiency and congenital malformations, racial/ethnic factors, poor obstetric history i.e. stillbirth and fetal growth restriction, genetic factors and issues with access to care. The following questions should be ascertained:
Duration of reduced fetal movements - when did the patient last feel the reduced fetal movements date and time
Absent fetal movements – duration and time

All clinicians must be aware of the potential association of decreased fetal movements with key risk factors such as fetal growth restriction (FGR), small gestational age (SGA) fetus, placental insufficiency and congenital malformation.

It is important that full details of the assessment and management are documented. It is also important to record the advice given about follow-up and when/where to present if a further episode of RFM is perceived.
During the history taking the midwife/obstetrician should check the following:
20 week gestational scan and placental localisation
Until  weeks gestation the anterior placenta is associated with the perception of reduced fetal movements
Baseline observation must be undertaken to include temperature, blood pressure, respirations and pulse.
As pre-eclampsia is associated with placental dysfunction, the woman's blood pressure must be measured and urine tested for proteinuria.
Following an abdominal palpation, including the symphysis fundal height (SFH)

which must be plotted on the woman's personalised GROW chart , an auscultation with a pinnard or hand held Doppler should ensue. Subsequently, a cardiotocograph (CTG) should be performed for at least  minutes, using a CTG monitor that records fetal movements.
(Refer to the guideline entitled ‘Abdominal palpation and examination in pregnancy' register number 07043)
If the criteria for a normal CTG are met the duration could range between 20, 60, or 90 minutes, the midwife should adhere to the following criteria:
Baseline: 100-160 beats per minute (bpm)
Variability: 5-25 bpm
No decelerations
Accelerations with fetal movements
If the above criteria have not been met, the patient must be monitored on the Oxford Sonicare CTG ( Computerised CTG).

Sonicaid FetalCare is an aid to clinical management, not a diagnosis, which remains the responsibility of an appropriately qualified expert. If the criteria have been met via the Oxford Sonicare CTG, (Computerised CTG) both this and the visual assessment mustbe considered and if the CTG is classified as normal, the monitoring can be discontinued. However, if the criteria has not been met the Oxford Sonicare CTG (Computerised CTG) should be continued for a period of 60 minutes, then stopped and printed for review by the obstetric registrar/
consultant on call
(Refer to the guideline entitled; ‘Fetal heart rate monitoring in pregnancy and labour' register number 04265.)

If the CTG is abnormal, the Obstetric Registrar /Consultant on call must be contacted to review the woman and CTG; who will then determine further action in the form of an individual plan of care for the woman.

A normal CTG in association with an active fetus carries a very high likelihood of normality and women can be reassured. However, a normal CTG has limitations as it only indicates normality at the time of the monitoring.

Once it is clear that the patient does not have reduced fetal movements, there are no other risk factors for stillbirth and there is a normal CTG, the woman can be reassured that 70% of pregnancies where there has been a single episode of reduced fetal movements are uncomplicated and the woman can be sent home without a medical review at the first visit.
Subsequent management in patients who present recurrently with
reduced fetal movements (RFM)

Women who present on two or more occasions with reduced fetal movements are at increased risk of a poor perinatal outcome. Women who present on a second visit for reduced fetal movements or subsequent visits thereafter should be reviewed by an obstetric registrar/ consultant on call. A CTG should be performed supplemented by further investigations. (Refer to point 5.7 to 5.9)
Definition of a recurrent episode of reduced fetal movements isnd episode within 4 weeks of the st episode of Reduced Fetal Movements. After 4 weeks the episode
reverts back to being the first episode. 6.3  Plan of Care for nd episode:
Perform CTG
Midwife to book an Ultrasound Scan (USS) on the next available date followed by a review with Obstetrics team on DAU or ANC.
If USS is going to be in > 4 days' time then twice weekly CTG until USS performed.

Women who present with a second episode of reduced fetal movement can have a CTG performed at the low risk unit either at WJC, Braintree or St Peters, Maldon. Women can then be booked for a fetal ultrasound scan (USS); on the next available date by the midwife. Following the USS the woman can be reviewed by the obstetric team in the Day Assessment Unit (DAU) at Broomfield Hospital.

Following the CTG monitoring and the USS both being normal and in absence of maternal or fetal risk factors; the episode closes i.e. if this woman subsequently presents (after a 4 week period) with further episodes of reduced fetal movements later on in pregnancy, a fresh pathway begins: CTG monitoring twice and follow- ups.
When a woman presents recurrently with reduced fetal movements the following plan should be adhered to:
Exclude predisposing causes
Ultrasound assessment every 2 weeks (include assessment of abdominal circumference and/or estimated fetal weight to detect the SGA fetus, and the assessment of amniotic fluid volume)
Oxford Sonicare CTG (Computerised CTG) 3 times a week
Obstetric Consultant review conducted and plan of care documented in the woman's healthcare records
The woman must be seen by her Obstetric Consultant Team in the Antenatal Clinic.
Management of patients who present with reduced fetal
movements before  weeks gestation

If a woman presents with reduced fetal movements prior to 24 weeks and 0 days gestation, the presence of a fetal heart rate must be confirmed by the midwife by auscultation with a Doppler handheld device.

If fetal movements have never been felt by  weeks of gestation, referral to a specialist fetal medicine unit must be considered to look for evidence of fetal neuromuscular conditions. A routine antenatal check-up must be carried out, including listening to the fetal heart.
Management of patients who present with reduced fetal
movements after  weeks to 28 weeks gestation

If a woman presents with reduced fetal movements between  weeks and 0 days and  weeks and 0 days of gestation, the presence of a fetal heartbeat must be confirmed by auscultation with a Doppler handheld device. The fetal heartbeat must be confirmed to check fetal viability.

The woman's history should include a comprehensive still birth risk evaluation; to include fetal growth restriction (FGR), hypertension, diabetes, extremes of maternal age, smoking, primiparity, placental insufficiency, congenital malformation, obesity, racial/ethnic factors, poor past obstetric history (FGR and stillbirth), genetic factors and issues with access to care.

Antenatal CTG must not be performed prior to  weeks unless instructed by a consultant obstetrician, this must then be performed only using the Dawes Redman analysis and this CTG must be reviewed by the obstetrician.
Management of patients who present with reduced fetal
movements after  weeks gestation
(Refer to Appendix A)

Ultrasound scan assessment must be undertaken as part of the preliminary investigations of a woman presenting with RFM after  weeks and 0 days gestation if the perception of RFM persists despite a normal CTG; or if there are any additional risk factors for fetal growth retardation.

The decision whether or not to induce labour at term in a woman who presents recurrently with reduced fetal movements when the growth, liquor volume and CTG appear normal is a Consultant-led decision. This must include a discussion of the pros and cons of induction on an individualised basis. If there are recurrent reduced fetal movements, consider IOL from  weeks onwards with a plan to deliver by  weeks. If a woman presents with reduced fetal movements after  week gestation an IOL must be recommended immediately.

After fetal viability has been confirmed and the woman's history confirms a decrease in fetal movements, arrangements must be made for the woman to have a CTG to exclude fetal compromise if the pregnancy is over 28 weeks and 0 days gestation.
Clinical suspicion of an SGA (small for gestational age) or IUGR
(intra uterine growth retardation) baby
If there is a clinical suspicion of an SGA or IUGR baby an ultrasound biometry must be booked by the obstetrician following an initial review by the obstetric registrar/ consultant on call.
A customized fundal height chart is generated with the GROW charts for every woman.
Criteria for performing an ultrasound scan
Criteria for performing an ultrasound scan:
CTG criteria not met either by CTG or Oxford Sonicare CTG (Computerised CTG)
Suspected SGA/ IUGR baby
Where SFH measurements suggest static, slow or excessive growth
Patient continues to perceive reduced fetal movements
Any other risk factor identified i.e. previous stillbirth

An ultrasound scan is required within as soon as possible but within 4 working days. Whilst awaiting USS twice weekly CTG must be performed until scan and Obstetric review. (Do not request a repeat growth scan measurements within  days of a previous test).
Staffing and training
All qualified midwifery and obstetric staff must be fully trained at CTG
interpretation as this skill is carried out on a daily basis. All midwifery and obstetric staff must attend yearly statutory training and further updates are mandatory
every six months.
(Refer to the guideline entitled ‘Mandatory training for Maternity Services (incorporating training needs analysis' register number 09062).

It is important that full details of assessment and management are documented. It is also important to record the advice given about follow-up and when/where to present if a further episode of reduced fetal movements is perceived. Refer to the guideline entitled ‘Maternity record keeping including documentation in handheld records'; register number 06036)
Guideline Management

12.3.1 As an integral part of the knowledge, skills framework, staff are appraised annually to ensure competency in computer skills and the ability to access the current approved guidelines via the Trust's intranet site.
Professional midwifery advocates

Professional Midwifery Advocates provide a mechanism of support and guidance to women and midwives. Professional Midwifery Advocates are experienced practising midwives who have undertaken further education in order to supervise midwifery services and to advise and support midwives and women in their care choices.
Infection prevention
All staff must ensure that they follow Trust guideline on infection prevention by washing their hands before and after each examination.

All staff must ensure that they follow Trust guidelines on infection prevention. All invasive devices must be inserted and cared for using High Impact Intervention guidelines to reduce the risk of infection and deliver safe care. This care must be recorded in the Saving Lives High Impact Intervention Monitoring Tool Paperwork (Medical Devices).
Audit and monitoring

table_items.text: Aspect of compliance or effectiveness being monitored
Individual department responsible for the monitoring
Group / Committee / forum which will receive the findings/monitoring report
Committee / individual responsible for ensuring the actions are completed
Women presenting with Reduced Fetal Movements

data.text: Audit of compliance with this guideline will be considered on an annual audit basis in accordance with the Clinical Audit Strategy and Policy and the Maternity annual audit work plan. The Women's and Children's Clinical Audit Group Audit Lead will identify a lead for the audit.

The findings of the audit will be reported to and approved by the Women's and Children's Clinical Audit Group and an action plan with named leads and timescales will be developed to address any identified deficiencies. Performance against the action plan will be monitored by this group at subsequent meetings.

The Women's and Children's Clinical Audit Group report will be reported to the Women's and Children's Directorate Governance Meeting and significant concerns relating to compliance will be entered on the local Risk Assurance Framework.
Key findings and learning points from the audit will be submitted to the Patient Safety Group within the integrated learning report.
Key findings and learning points will be disseminated to relevant staff.
Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved locally by the Maternity and Gynaecology Practice Steering Group prior to submission to the Controlled Document team for ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.

It is the Guidelines and Audit Nurse's and author's responsibility to inform the Maternity and Gynaecology Practice Steering Group and appropriate Maternity Services' staff of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
This Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals. (Refer to appendix
